content.question: Choose a reason for your divorce
content.explanation: You must choose one of the following reasons (legally known as the 'facts') for your divorce.
content.separatedDetails: What if we lived together after we separated?
content.sameResidenceHeading: Living in the same residence while separated
content.sameResidenceSummary: You can still live in the same residence while separated, as long you're not living together as a couple, for example, you don't eat, sleep or cook together.
content.asACoupleHeading: Living together as a couple after separating
content.asACoupleSummary1: If you have lived together as a couple after separating, you can't use the
content.asACoupleSummary2: facts if it was for more than 6 months, during or after the separation period. This can have been either in a single period or over several periods.
content.asACoupleSummary3: Any time you spent living as a couple doesn't count towards the separation period, and you'll need to make up any time you were together before you apply for a divorce.
content.2Years: Living together as a couple after separating
content.5Years: 2 years separation with consent, 5 years separation and desertion
content.chooseAReason: Choose one of the following reasons:
content.unreasonableBehaviourSummary: Your {{ divorceWho }} has behaved in such a way that you can't reasonably be expected to live with them any more
content.unreasonableBehaviourWarning: You'll be asked to provide examples of the behaviour. If you have lived together as a couple for a period or periods totalling more than 6 months since the most recent incident you rely on, the court may take that into account in its decision on whether to grant you a divorce.
content.adulterySummary1: Your {{ divorceWho }} has committed adultery with a
content.adulterySummary2: and you find it intolerable (unbearable) to live with them. Adultery can only be used if it was with a member of the opposite sex
content.adulteryWarning: You can still use this reason if you continued to live together as a married couple afterwards; eg you still ate, slept, and cooked together. However, this can only have been for up to 6 months after you found out about the adultery - you'll have to choose another reason if it's more.
content.2YearsSeparationSummary: Your {{ divorceWho }} agrees to a divorce and you've been separated for 2 years or more
content.2YearsSeparationWarning: The court will ask your {{ divorceWho }} if they agree to a divorce. If they don't agree, your application will be rejected and you'll need to choose another reason.
content.2YearsSeparationExclusion: You can use this reason if you have been separated for at least 2 years since you married, and only if your {{ divorceWho }} agrees
content.5YearsSeparationSummary: You've been separated from your {{ divorceWho }} for 5 years or more
content.5YearsSeparationExclusion: You can use this reason if you have been separated from your {{divorceWho}} for 5 years or more. The earliest you can use this reason is
content.desertionSummary: Your {{ divorceWho }} abandoned you (left without your agreement) more than 2 years ago
content.desertionExclusion: You can use this reason if your {{ divorceWho }} abandoned you (left without your agreement) more than 2 years ago
content.unableToChoose1: Based on the date of your marriage, some reasons aren't available for you to use until
content.noneApply: If you can't use any of these reasons, you may be able to get a legal separation or annul your marriage.
